author: cian riordan
content:
A tangent…

I’m lucky to have spent many years in a great studio with lots of great drums & gear… not to mention being mentored by one of the great engineers of our time. Having this perspective is massively useful in mixing other peoples tracks, because I feel I have a north star of what good drums can sound like if they’re recorded and performed properly. It used to be that my starting point for mixing drums were working with tracks that I had recorded myself… and most of the above problems were solved before the mix stage. These days, with smaller budgets and time constraints, its very rare that this is a possibility.

I’m including this drum tracking session from a few years ago that I recorded at Barefoot. It was for a project that Matt was producing that never saw the light of day. But we went all out with the drum setup in the big room, through the console, and had a great drummer. This might be useful for some people who have never gotten properly recorded drum tracks… to get a sense of how good thigns can sound before the ‘mix’ stage. These are the tracks that were printed into Pro Tools off of the console, and the three busses were prints of the outboard compressor busses we were using while monitoring. It’s unlikely these busses would get used in mixing, but they’re a good reference to what we were listening to in the room while we were tracking. But as you’ll notice, the individual drum blend can stand on it’s own two feet. Hopefully this is useful as well.

Thanks for coming to my Ted talk.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Man. 85 percent of the tracks I’d get would require an hour of trying to line up the song PROPERLY to the grid. It’s not as easy as lining a kick to the grid as half you guys are using kick samples that have space before the transient.  When I’m out here nudging and stretching vocals at 1/1000th of second resolutions, which can dramatically change the pocket and vibe, it’s a kick in the teeth then if the whole track ends up being a tenth of a second off. 

The trick I came up with was putting four low frequency Square wave bursts maybe an 1/8th note long each at the beginning or end of each song. That means at no matter the master bus processing (or worse the mp3 meta data at the beginning pushing the song back) you can recalibrate EXACTLY the track back on to the grid. In that case, once you’ve figured that bit out, slap whatever you want on the bus. The square wave trick is how we were able to prove how logic or ableton was bouncing out of time even when a ton of people didn’t hear it or notice.

author: cian riordan
content:
1) Yes! All MPDI-4 mic pres. Signal chain would have been Mic -> Pre -> UTA Console Line In -> Pro Tools.

2) I’m pretty sure this would’ve been a Frankenstein. Most likely Eric’s Sonor birch kick drum with a Remo Black Dot on it. Almost certainly Vistalite toms… and this sounds like a Bell Brass snare.

3) Room mics are placed probably 20 feet away, spaced wide, pointed at the kit. Eric would always point the room mics away from the drums with the cardioid null towards the drum kit, but I found I got more direct, punchy sounds with it facing the drums. Chamber mics would’ve been a foot apart, pointed 45 degs out… sort of intentionally phasey to make them wider.

4) Yeah, you’re onto it. The overheads are intentionally wide and close to the cymbals. The mono mic and close mics are doing the heavy lifting with the drums and the L/R OHs are almost just cymbal spot mics with some kit stereo information peppered in.

5) Saturation is a combination of driving the UTA pres, clipping the line input of the console, and trimming things back with the faders. Might’ve been an LA-2a on the snare with no compression, just crapping out the tubes.

Sorry wish I woulda taken pictures of this session. Dave Elitch was the drummer and he’s a fucking monster.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I love my dear friend @BatMeckley but I think he's wrong here. Just send the instrumental how it sounds the best, and have them send you a bounced ref along with the vocal. I ask them to send me the session too as I have Pro Tools, Logic, and Ableton and can play with their processing and do a new bounce if need be.

If a vocal bounce comes back with some delay uncompensated or otherwise off the grid, lining up the vocal will NOT take you an hour. You simply line up the ref to your session and the vocal to the ref (the latter is 99% of time already done since they're bouncing from the same session). This takes a few minutes max and I've done it dozens of times. Nudge and flip some phase and you're within a couple samples. You're fine.

author: cian riordan
content:
I started getting serious about recording while I was in college (studying chemistry). I was playing bass in a band at the time and I was the only one that had any sort of decent recording equipment. I found myself being the guy recording all of the band's demos before we went into a 'proper studio'. Eventually, we realized my demos were sounding better than the ones we paid other people to record! Meanwhile, I started assisting (for free) at a local small recording studio and met a really great mentor. The studio was small and its business was mostly weekend warrior type stuff – nobody really notable. That being said, it was a working studio – and booked almost 6-7 days a week. The producer was the big fish in the small pond and had a great repeat clientele. Most of the music was not my cup of tea – but this proved to be a good thing as I was exposed to all sorts of different styles and it allowed me to be comfortable in genres of music which I normally wouldn't gravitate towards. It just made me comfortable around music and musicians in general.

Once I graduated and decided I wasn't going to use my chemistry degree, I ended up helping the producer build a bigger studio complex from the ground up. I learned an insane amount of stuff during this period – whether it was researching which Pro Tools system we would need to helping design the wiring layout to actually implementing it all. Ultimately, after months of hard work (and lots of borrowed money) the studio was complete and it was ready for business. I worked here for 2 years or so until I got introduced to Eric Valentine through former Street To Nowhere guitarist Matt Radosevich in Los Angeles. He needed a new full-time assistant and so I hopped at the opportunity and moved to LA – leaving behind the studio and crew I helped build (they're still going today and they're doing great).

author: Josh Bowman
content:
EQ is powerful! 

Are you making the moves with elements in solo or in the context of the mix? Try out both. Solo is easier to hear what your doing to the thing, but eqing the element in context of the song/mix makes it easier to hear if your killing the vibe. I'd guess most people will encourage in-context EQing for this reason.

The reaper EQ is likely not the issue. Experiment with all the diff filters and shapes for sure! Best way to learn is to try it out. 

Also, eqing something and then undoing it later because it isnt better happens all the time while im mixing. Its great that you're double checking your moves later and trying to be objective about if its an improvement or not. Also- SOMETIMES its a boost not a cut thats needed. Too much bottom, maybe add some top or mids to balance it out instead of cutting bottom (just an example). See how that feels instead.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Neat question. If you're mixing in two channels (L/R) the headroom should be the same no matter where you pan it (with some caveats which we'll get to). If you have a kick drum panned dead center coming in at -6dB on your digital meter it's going to be coming in at -6 in both the L channel and -6 in the R channel. Each channel has it's own independent headroom that doesn't affect the other (until we add a limiter with linked channels), so let's simplify things a bit and mute the R channel for now:

Now you have your L channel with the kick panned "center" and the R channel is muted.  If you were to pan this kick to the hard left it would not affect the volume of the L channel at all. That's because the panning effect is created by subtracting gain from the R channel only. Making the kick sound like it's leaning to the left.

Now there's one big element I've left out so far, and that's *pan law*. Ableton Live has a -3dB pan law. This means that sounds panned to the center are reduced by 3dB. Because if a sound is being played at the same volume by both the L and R channels then their voltage will combine to create a sound that is louder than intended. So all DAWs and mixers compensate for this added loudness by turning down the gain of sounds as they are panned closer to the center (and shared between both speakers).

Since all modern DAWs and mixers have pan laws implemented, what happens when you now pan the kick hard left is that it ends up becoming 3dB louder than it was when it was panned in the center, because it is no longer being turned down by the pan law when it’s centered.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Perhaps I can address your issue at the source with how you have your Ableton compressor set up:

You're saying that you cannot get your 808 to duck low enough each time the kick hits. The first thing that stands out to me is that you're using a soft ratio. You need to crank that ratio up to at *least* a 4:1 ratio, but you might be even better off with an 8:1 or higher ratio. You need a high ratio to get the deeper ducking effect that it seems you're seeking.

Using a soft ratio will never get you a big duck unless you have the threshold pulled all of the way down. And even then it's probably going to have issues recovering correctly after each duck.

author: Zack Hames
content:
2 Questions:

1. Does anyone have a reason to *not* use 32 Bit Float as opposed to 24 bit depth? I've stuck with 24 out of habit, but 32 seems to have 0 downfalls, besides space usage.

2. I am having trouble monitoring hardware inserts without the obvious latency, even when I figure out the time delay in Pro Tools. Is there something I'm missing? I imagine there has to be a way to monitor hardware inserts in real time and have it be in sync (Delaying all the tracks to be in sync).

author: mixedbywong_my
content:
I read this on reaper blog a while back when I was wondering this same question , 

This is what i found 
“To summarize:

32-bit offers absolutely no benefit in terms of sound quality or headroom as a recording bit-depth. Use 24-bit for recording.

32-bit allows you to “unclip” and remove distortion of audio that was captured within the DAW. For rendering virtual instruments or freezing tracks that might go above 0dbFS use 32-bit.”

author: chadwahlbrink
content: In regards to 32-bit, I try to stick with 32bit until Mastering. This is mainly out of an "abundance of caution," but basically, it's theoretically possible to have rounding errors/quantization distortion (granted at like -128dB) when bouncing between the 32-bit processing within the DAW and other processing like izotope RX or even just bouncing stems from one person to another. Note - there is also a settting in pro tools to "always use 32-bit for audiosuite processing" for this reason! Also, you can just use a 24bit dither when you go from 32 to 24bit at mastering stage as needed (if you are providing the master).

author: benigma
content: Hey all, got a question about sidechaining in Ableton, specifically kicks and bass/808s. I normally just use a generic compressor when sidechaining with a soft ratio, no attack/short release, and pretty low threshold (-18 to -24) and it usually works pretty well. Sometimes however the compressor alone isn't enough to dip the 808 and allow the kick to punch through cleanly. I was going to try using F6 instead, but I can't figure out how to sidechain the kick signal itself into F6 (in Ableton at least). Any tips?

author: Adam Thein
content:
Should just be two steps:

On 3rd party plugins in live that allow sidechaining, you should see this little Sidechain menu show up.  So this should look really similar to the sidechain settings in the stock compressor. (1st picture)

Next, inside the plugin there should be an option to change the source of the sidechain to "external" from default internal.  With the stock Ableton plugins this happens automatically when you engage the sidechain but for 3rd party you have to add it manually. author: cian riordan
content:
This is a very broad question with many different answers, but I think the easiest way to sum up the concept of ‘gain staging’ is simply figuring out what level every ‘device’ is expecting and/or which level is ideal to get the results you want. These ‘devices’ can be a plugin, a piece of hardware, an A/D/A converter, an auxiliary bus, a mix bus, etc.

In analog world… there might be fathomable difference when a compressor or amplifier receives -10dBVU vs +10 dBVU. Accounting for these differences would be considered gain staging — and you’d be looking for what gets the ideal sound out of your box.

In digital world… some plugins may react similarly and others may not care if you’re sending -6dBFS or -0.01dBFS. It’s usually case by case as there are myriad plugins. You also need to consider what level the plugin is sending signal out — as this will affect how the next plugin processes the audio, or how much headroom it has to work with. Let’s say I’m sending signal out of a compressor plugin into an EQ plugin — and lets say I’m using the compressor to beef up mean volume of the signal and then I want to EQ some more low end into the signal after the fact. Well, I’m going to be adding gain in the compressor and then the level going into the EQ will be hotter than originally intended. Id want to trim down the output of the compressor (or the input of the EQ) so you have headroom to be able to boost those frequencies without clipping the output of the EQ. In a 32-bit floating mixer like Pro Tools, these issues become less audible as the mixer has higher headroom than its indicating, but you never actually know — and it’s best to just stick to the parameters that you have control over. If you were to do this same function with an analog compressor and EQ, there would be very noticeable distortion if you didn’t stage the gain properly.

author: cian riordan
content:
Sometimes gain staging is just managing the signals going to an auxiliary bus or a master fader. If you’ve got everything summing into - say - an aux bus in pro tools, and that aux bus is clipping, then that will be audible distortion going into the next gain stage. It may sound good, it probably doesn’t — so its something to account for earlier down the chain. If you’re going into a master fader in pro tools, and your signal is over 0dBFS, you can simply turn down the master fader, and it is actually turning down all the signals going to it, not just the output. This is useful because you can then throttle the input to your first plugin in the chain — say a limiter or maximizer. It’d be a shame to have a fancy clipper on your master bus, only to be clipping the signal in the chain before even getting to it.

It’s a bit of a scattershot answer to a scattershot question, but the reality is that everything affects everything in audio. And having your head wrapped around signals levels going in and out of things will help you make faster decisions and help you troubleshoot quickly when things aren’t sounding quite right.

author: Adam Thein
content:
I’d take a look at the interface software - are the outputs to 3+4 turned up in the audient software?  Are you getting visual feedback of signal hitting those channels outside Ableton?

My guess is a software thing with the Audient mixer.

I have been trying to do that forever. 2. Slip Edit in Reaper and Cubase 3. Use Stretch Markers in Reaper and nudge around little pockets of sound. Now, I have a TRUE and UNIQUE disdain for Reaper. I think it's unintuitive, I think it's cumbersome, I shudder to think of all the time I spent fiddling around with this Nerd-god of a fucking daw when I could've been soaring along in Cubase or Protools, and I'm honestly so, soo sick of it, but... as I'm sitting here with my Dell Lattiude laptop from 2013 with its 8 gigs of ram, trying to install Pro Tools Intro for the 5th time (wheel spinning for minutes on end and then just spontaneously shutting down), I'm thinking to myself, "Is there any reason I shouldn't just dig my heels into Reaper and finish up this one album with it??" There are some things I like about Reaper, and the fact that I now preeeetty much know what I need to in order to finish things out, I mean... I've got some serious technological limitations over here. Pro tools intro took 3 hours to download and I'm not even able to install it on my computer. Reaper runs fine (so does Cubase LE4)... I hate it, but I mean... This is where I'm at... Thank you, All.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Here’s gain staging in a nut shell: don’t clip. In pro tools I try to keep all my faders at 0 or below. Seems to play nice and I don’t ever go back at the end of my mix to push everything down.

Make sure you aren’t clipping within plugins either. Fabfilter pro-Q 3 is notoriously nasty sounding when clipped.

author: spectrummasters
content: Ya , fwiw : I like (in Logic Pro ) faders at zero , peaking at -8 in the channels . Touch the faders for balance . Usually peak about -3 in sub groups  buses . Sub group master faders all at -5 from start of mix . Usually ending up about -2 peak in masterbus , 2 bus comp threshold / input gain will adjust to what this number is to get the 3 db peak max I’m looking for usually

author: Zack Hames
content:
what you're saying makes sense. Couple things to try;

1. different click sound! I really like "marimba 2" in pro tools for some reason. really easy to hear always, feels REALLY on time.

2. Maybe try having a timed delay on one of your drum signals you can play off of. like a 1/16 note or triplet echo very faintly that, when you're in the pocket, grooves with your drumming. might be tough if you're doing really busy proggy stuff or if you're really worried about timing from an OCD perspective.

3. if you have scratch guitar/bass tracks that were tracked to a click/perfectly gridded drum thing, playing along to that is usually far more inspiring and you can rely less on the click because you can just listen to the instruments.

4. This is where having someone else record you helps. you might be totally in your head about this. a "producer" could be like "bro that take was legit perfect"
